main event: On June 7, 1957, a ground-radar observation was conducted by the U.S. Army in Fishkill, New York, lasting 15 minutes. The object(s) appeared as spots of light slightly larger than stars and were picked up by ground radar and observed visually.
interesting points: The object(s) were spotted by ground radar and observed visually, appearing as spots of light slightly larger than stars.
The report suggested that the observed objects could possibly be satellites, balloons, or aircraft, indicating uncertainty about the nature of the sightings.
The observation lasted for 15 minutes, providing a significant duration for the sighting.
The location of the sighting was 8 miles east of SWF, near Fishkill, New York, with weather conditions including partial overcast and scattered thunderstorms.
The controller, W.T. Livingstone, made no comment on the sighting.
result: Possibly Satellite, Possibly Balloon, Possibly Aircraft
sighted object: Spot of light(s) slightly larger than stars in the sky
